segment.source: This article describes how to create a Windows Runtime Compontent that implements the IBasicVideoEffect interface to allows you to create custom effects for video streams.
segment.target: This article describes how to create a Windows Runtime Compontent that implements the IBasicVideoEffect interface to allows you to create custom effects for video streams.

segment.source: Custom video effects
segment.target: Custom video effects

segment.source: Custom video effects
segment.target: Custom video effects

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: \[Some information relates to pre-released product which may be substantially modified before it's commercially released.
segment.target: \[Some information relates to pre-released product which may be substantially modified before it's commercially released.

segment.source: Microsoft makes no warranties, express or implied, with respect to the information provided here.\]
segment.target: Microsoft makes no warranties, express or implied, with respect to the information provided here.\]

segment.source: This article describes how to create a Windows Runtime Compontent that implements the IBasicVideoEffect interface to allows you to create custom effects for video streams.
segment.target: This article describes how to create a Windows Runtime Compontent that implements the IBasicVideoEffect interface to allows you to create custom effects for video streams.

segment.source: Custom effects can be used with several different Windows Runtime APIs including MediaCapture, which provides access to a device's camera, and MediaComposition, which allows you to create complex compositions out of media clips.
segment.target: Custom effects can be used with several different Windows Runtime APIs including MediaCapture, which provides access to a device's camera, and MediaComposition, which allows you to create complex compositions out of media clips.

segment.source: Add a custom effect to your app
segment.target: Add a custom effect to your app

segment.source: A custom video effect is defined in a class that implements the IBasicVideoEffect interface.
segment.target: A custom video effect is defined in a class that implements the IBasicVideoEffect interface.

segment.source: This class can't be included directly in your app's project.
segment.target: This class can't be included directly in your app's project.

segment.source: Instead, you must use a Windows Runtime Component to host your video effect class.
segment.target: Instead, you must use a Windows Runtime Component to host your video effect class.

segment.source: Add a Windows Runtime Component for your video effect
segment.target: Add a Windows Runtime Component for your video effect

segment.source: In Microsoft Visual Studio, with your solution open, go to the File menu and select Add-New Project....
segment.target: In Microsoft Visual Studio, with your solution open, go to the File menu and select Add-New Project....

segment.source: Select the Windows Runtime Component (Universal Windows) project type.
segment.target: Select the Windows Runtime Component (Universal Windows) project type.

segment.source: For this example, name the project "VideoEffectComponent".
segment.target: For this example, name the project "VideoEffectComponent".

segment.source: This name will be referenced in code later.
segment.target: This name will be referenced in code later.

segment.source: Click OK.
segment.target: Click OK.

segment.source: The project template creates a class called Class1.cs.
segment.target: The project template creates a class called Class1.cs.

segment.source: In Solution Explorer, right-click the icon for Class1.cs and select Rename.
segment.target: In Solution Explorer, right-click the icon for Class1.cs and select Rename.

segment.source: Rename the file to "ExampleVideoEffect.cs".
segment.target: Rename the file to "ExampleVideoEffect.cs".

segment.source: Visual Studio will show a prompt asking if you want to update all references to the new name.
segment.target: Visual Studio will show a prompt asking if you want to update all references to the new name.

segment.source: Click Yes.
segment.target: Click Yes.

segment.source: Open "ExampleVideoEffect.cs" and update the class definition to implement the IBasicVideoEffect interface.
segment.target: Open "ExampleVideoEffect.cs" and update the class definition to implement the IBasicVideoEffect interface.

segment.source: ImplementIBasicVideoEffect
segment.target: ImplementIBasicVideoEffect

segment.source: You need to include the following namespaces in your effect class file in order to access all of the types used in the examples in this article.
segment.target: You need to include the following namespaces in your effect class file in order to access all of the types used in the examples in this article.

segment.source: EffectUsing
segment.target: EffectUsing

segment.source: Implement the IBasicVideoEffect interface using software processing
segment.target: Implement the IBasicVideoEffect interface using software processing

segment.source: Your video effect must implement all of the methods and properties of the IBasicVideoEffect interface.
segment.target: Your video effect must implement all of the methods and properties of the IBasicVideoEffect interface.

segment.source: This section walks you through a simple implementation of this interface that uses software processing.
segment.target: This section walks you through a simple implementation of this interface that uses software processing.

segment.source: Close method
segment.target: Close method

segment.source: The system will call the Close method on your class when the effect should shut down.
segment.target: The system will call the Close method on your class when the effect should shut down.

segment.source: You should use this method to dispose of any resources you have created.
segment.target: You should use this method to dispose of any resources you have created.

segment.source: The argument to the method is a MediaEffectClosedReason that lets you know whether the effect was closed normally, if an error occurred, or if the effect does not support the required encoding format.
segment.target: The argument to the method is a MediaEffectClosedReason that lets you know whether the effect was closed normally, if an error occurred, or if the effect does not support the required encoding format.

segment.source: Close
segment.target: Close

segment.source: DiscardQueuedFrames method
segment.target: DiscardQueuedFrames method

segment.source: The DiscardQueuedFrames method is called when your effect should reset.
segment.target: The DiscardQueuedFrames method is called when your effect should reset.

segment.source: A typical scenario for this is if your effect stores previously processed frames to use in processing the current frame.
segment.target: A typical scenario for this is if your effect stores previously processed frames to use in processing the current frame.

segment.source: When this method is called, you should dispose of the set of previous frames you have saved.
segment.target: When this method is called, you should dispose of the set of previous frames you have saved.

segment.source: Although this method can be used to reset any state related to previous frames, not only accumulated video frames.
segment.target: Although this method can be used to reset any state related to previous frames, not only accumulated video frames.

segment.source: DiscardQueuedFrames
segment.target: DiscardQueuedFrames

segment.source: IsReadOnly property
segment.target: IsReadOnly property

segment.source: The IsReadOnly property lets the system know if your effect will write to the output of the effect.
segment.target: The IsReadOnly property lets the system know if your effect will write to the output of the effect.

segment.source: If your app does not modify the video frames - for example, an effect that only performs analysis of the video frames - then you should set this property to true, which will cause the system to efficiently copy the frame input to the frame output for you.
segment.target: If your app does not modify the video frames - for example, an effect that only performs analysis of the video frames - then you should set this property to true, which will cause the system to efficiently copy the frame input to the frame output for you.

segment.source: Tip When the IsReadOnly property is set to true, the system copies the input frame to the output frame before ProcessFrame is called.
segment.target: Tip When the IsReadOnly property is set to true, the system copies the input frame to the output frame before ProcessFrame is called.

segment.source: Setting the IsReadOnly property to true does not restrict you from writing to the effect's output frames in ProcessFrame.
segment.target: Setting the IsReadOnly property to true does not restrict you from writing to the effect's output frames in ProcessFrame.

segment.source: IsReadOnly
segment.target: IsReadOnly

segment.source: SetEncodingProperties method
segment.target: SetEncodingProperties method

segment.source: The system calls SetEncodingProperties on your effect to let you know the encoding properties for the video stream upon which the effect is operating.
segment.target: The system calls SetEncodingProperties on your effect to let you know the encoding properties for the video stream upon which the effect is operating.

segment.source: This method also provides a reference to the Direct3D device used for hardware rendering.
segment.target: This method also provides a reference to the Direct3D device used for hardware rendering.

segment.source: The usage of this device is shown in the hardware processing example later in this article.
segment.target: The usage of this device is shown in the hardware processing example later in this article.

segment.source: SetEncodingProperties
segment.target: SetEncodingProperties

segment.source: SupportedEncodingProperties property
segment.target: SupportedEncodingProperties property

segment.source: The system checks the SupportedEncodingProperties property to determine which encoding properties are supported by your effect.
segment.target: The system checks the SupportedEncodingProperties property to determine which encoding properties are supported by your effect.

segment.source: Note that if the consumer of your effect can't encode video using the properties you specify, it will call Close on your effect and will remove your effect from the video pipeline.
segment.target: Note that if the consumer of your effect can't encode video using the properties you specify, it will call Close on your effect and will remove your effect from the video pipeline.

segment.source: SupportedEncodingProperties
segment.target: SupportedEncodingProperties

segment.source: Note If you return an empty list of VideoEncodingProperties objects from SupportedEncodingProperties, the system will default to ARGB32 encoding.
segment.target: Note If you return an empty list of VideoEncodingProperties objects from SupportedEncodingProperties, the system will default to ARGB32 encoding.

segment.source: SupportedMemoryTypes property
segment.target: SupportedMemoryTypes property

segment.source: The system checks the SupportedMemoryTypes property to determine whether your effect will access video frames in software memory or in hardware (GPU) memory.
segment.target: The system checks the SupportedMemoryTypes property to determine whether your effect will access video frames in software memory or in hardware (GPU) memory.

segment.source: If you return MediaMemoryTypes.Cpu, your effect will be passed input and output frames that contain image data in SoftwareBitmap objects.
segment.target: If you return MediaMemoryTypes.Cpu, your effect will be passed input and output frames that contain image data in SoftwareBitmap objects.

segment.source: If you return MediaMemoryTypes.Gpu, your effect will be passed input and output frames that contain image data in IDirect3DSurface objects.
segment.target: If you return MediaMemoryTypes.Gpu, your effect will be passed input and output frames that contain image data in IDirect3DSurface objects.

segment.source: SupportedMemoryTypes
segment.target: SupportedMemoryTypes

segment.source: Note If you specify MediaMemoryTypes.GpuAndCpu, the system will use either GPU or system memory, whichever is more efficient for the pipeline.
segment.target: Note If you specify MediaMemoryTypes.GpuAndCpu, the system will use either GPU or system memory, whichever is more efficient for the pipeline.

segment.source: When using this value, you must check in the ProcessFrame method to see whether the SoftwareBitmap or IDirect3DSurface passed into the method contains data and then process the frame accordingly.
segment.target: When using this value, you must check in the ProcessFrame method to see whether the SoftwareBitmap or IDirect3DSurface passed into the method contains data and then process the frame accordingly.

segment.source: TimeIndependent property
segment.target: TimeIndependent property

segment.source: The TimeIndependent property lets the system know whether your effect requires uniform timing.
segment.target: The TimeIndependent property lets the system know whether your effect requires uniform timing.

segment.source: When set to true, the system can use optimizations that enhance effect performance.
segment.target: When set to true, the system can use optimizations that enhance effect performance.

segment.source: TimeIndependent
segment.target: TimeIndependent

segment.source: SetProperties method
segment.target: SetProperties method

segment.source: The SetProperties method allows the app that is using your effect to adjust effect parameters.
segment.target: The SetProperties method allows the app that is using your effect to adjust effect parameters.

segment.source: Properties are passed as an IPropertySet map of property names and values.
segment.target: Properties are passed as an IPropertySet map of property names and values.

segment.source: SetProperties
segment.target: SetProperties

segment.source: This simple example will dim the pixels in each video frame according to a specified value.
segment.target: This simple example will dim the pixels in each video frame according to a specified value.

segment.source: A property is declared and TryGetValue is used to get the value set by the calling app.
segment.target: A property is declared and TryGetValue is used to get the value set by the calling app.

segment.source: If no value was set, a default value of .5 is used.
segment.target: If no value was set, a default value of .5 is used.

segment.source: FadeValue
segment.target: FadeValue

segment.source: ProcessFrame method
segment.target: ProcessFrame method

segment.source: The ProcessFrame method is where your effect modifies the image data of the video.
segment.target: The ProcessFrame method is where your effect modifies the image data of the video.

segment.source: The method is called once per frame and is passed a ProcessVideoFrameContext object.
segment.target: The method is called once per frame and is passed a ProcessVideoFrameContext object.

segment.source: This object contains an input VideoFrame object that contains the incoming frame to be processed and an output VideoFrame object to which you write image data that will be passed on to rest of the video pipeline.
segment.target: This object contains an input VideoFrame object that contains the incoming frame to be processed and an output VideoFrame object to which you write image data that will be passed on to rest of the video pipeline.

segment.source: Each of these VideoFrame objects has a SoftwareBitmap property and a Direct3DSurface property, but which of these can be used is determined by the value you returned from the SupportedMemoryTypes property.
segment.target: Each of these VideoFrame objects has a SoftwareBitmap property and a Direct3DSurface property, but which of these can be used is determined by the value you returned from the SupportedMemoryTypes property.

segment.source: This example shows a simple implementation of the ProcessFrame method using software processing.
segment.target: This example shows a simple implementation of the ProcessFrame method using software processing.

segment.source: For more information on working with SoftwareBitmap objects, see Imaging.
segment.target: For more information on working with SoftwareBitmap objects, see Imaging.

segment.source: An example ProcessFrame implementation using hardware processing is shown later in this article.
segment.target: An example ProcessFrame implementation using hardware processing is shown later in this article.

segment.source: Accessing the data buffer of a SoftwareBitmap requires COM interop, so you should include the System.Runtime.InteropServices namespace in your effect class file.
segment.target: Accessing the data buffer of a SoftwareBitmap requires COM interop, so you should include the System.Runtime.InteropServices namespace in your effect class file.

segment.source: COMUsing
segment.target: COMUsing

segment.source: Add the following code inside the namespace for your effect to import the interface for accessing the image buffer.
segment.target: Add the following code inside the namespace for your effect to import the interface for accessing the image buffer.

segment.source: COMImport
segment.target: COMImport

segment.source: Note Because this technique accesses a native, unmanaged image buffer, you will need to configure your project to allow unsafe code.
segment.target: Note Because this technique accesses a native, unmanaged image buffer, you will need to configure your project to allow unsafe code.

segment.source: In Solution Explorer, right-click the VideoEffectComponent project and select Properties....
segment.target: In Solution Explorer, right-click the VideoEffectComponent project and select Properties....

segment.source: Select the Build tab.
segment.target: Select the Build tab.

segment.source: Check the checkbox for "Allow unsafe code"
segment.target: Check the checkbox for "Allow unsafe code"

segment.source: Now you can add the ProcessFrame method implementation.
segment.target: Now you can add the ProcessFrame method implementation.

segment.source: First, this method obtains a BitmapBuffer object from both the input and output software bitmaps.
segment.target: First, this method obtains a BitmapBuffer object from both the input and output software bitmaps.

segment.source: Note that the output frame is opened for writing and the input for reading.
segment.target: Note that the output frame is opened for writing and the input for reading.

segment.source: Next, an IMemoryBufferReference is obtained for each buffer by calling CreateReference.
segment.target: Next, an IMemoryBufferReference is obtained for each buffer by calling CreateReference.

segment.source: Then, the actual data buffer is obtained by casting the IMemoryBufferReference objects as the COM interop interface defined above, IMemoryByteAccess, and then calling GetBuffer.
segment.target: Then, the actual data buffer is obtained by casting the IMemoryBufferReference objects as the COM interop interface defined above, IMemoryByteAccess, and then calling GetBuffer.

segment.source: Now that the data buffers have been obtained, you can read from the input buffer and write to the output buffer.
segment.target: Now that the data buffers have been obtained, you can read from the input buffer and write to the output buffer.

segment.source: The layout of the buffer is obtained by calling GetPlaneDescription, which provides information on the width, stride, and initial offset of the buffer.
segment.target: The layout of the buffer is obtained by calling GetPlaneDescription, which provides information on the width, stride, and initial offset of the buffer.

segment.source: The bits per pixel is determined by the encoding properties set previously with the SetEncodingProperties method.
segment.target: The bits per pixel is determined by the encoding properties set previously with the SetEncodingProperties method.

segment.source: The buffer format information is used to find the index into the buffer for each pixel.
segment.target: The buffer format information is used to find the index into the buffer for each pixel.

segment.source: The pixel value from the source buffer is copied into the target buffer, with the color values being multiplied by the FadeValue property defined for this effect to dim them by the specified amount.
segment.target: The pixel value from the source buffer is copied into the target buffer, with the color values being multiplied by the FadeValue property defined for this effect to dim them by the specified amount.

segment.source: ProcessFrameSoftwareBitmap
segment.target: ProcessFrameSoftwareBitmap

segment.source: Implement the IBasicVideoEffect interface using hardware processing
segment.target: Implement the IBasicVideoEffect interface using hardware processing

segment.source: Creating a custom video effect using hardware (GPU) processing is almost identical to using software processing as described above.
segment.target: Creating a custom video effect using hardware (GPU) processing is almost identical to using software processing as described above.

segment.source: This section will show the few differences in an effect that uses hardware processing.
segment.target: This section will show the few differences in an effect that uses hardware processing.

segment.source: This example uses the Win2D Windows Runtime API.
segment.target: This example uses the Win2D Windows Runtime API.

segment.source: For more information on using Win2D, see the Win2D documentation.
segment.target: For more information on using Win2D, see the Win2D documentation.

segment.source: Use the following steps to add the Win2D NuGet package to the project you created as described in the Add a custom effect to your app section at the beginning of this article.
segment.target: Use the following steps to add the Win2D NuGet package to the project you created as described in the Add a custom effect to your app section at the beginning of this article.

segment.source: Add the Win2D NuGet package to your effect project
segment.target: Add the Win2D NuGet package to your effect project

segment.source: In Solution Explorer, right-click the VideoEffectComponent project and select Manage NuGet Packages...
segment.target: In Solution Explorer, right-click the VideoEffectComponent project and select Manage NuGet Packages...

segment.source: At the top of the window, select the Browse tab.
segment.target: At the top of the window, select the Browse tab.

segment.source: In the search box, type "Win2D".
segment.target: In the search box, type "Win2D".

segment.source: Click on Win2D.uwp and the click Install in the right pane.
segment.target: Click on Win2D.uwp and the click Install in the right pane.

segment.source: The Review Changes dialog shows you the package to be installed.
segment.target: The Review Changes dialog shows you the package to be installed.

segment.source: Click OK.
segment.target: Click OK.

segment.source: Accept the package license.
segment.target: Accept the package license.

segment.source: In addition to the namespaces included in the basic project setup, you will need to include the following namespaces provided by Win2D.
segment.target: In addition to the namespaces included in the basic project setup, you will need to include the following namespaces provided by Win2D.

segment.source: UsingWin2D
segment.target: UsingWin2D

segment.source: Because this effect will use GPU memory for operating on the image data, you should return MediaMemoryTypes.Gpu from the SupportedMemoryTypes property.
segment.target: Because this effect will use GPU memory for operating on the image data, you should return MediaMemoryTypes.Gpu from the SupportedMemoryTypes property.

segment.source: SupportedMemoryTypesWin2D
segment.target: SupportedMemoryTypesWin2D

segment.source: Set the encoding properties your effect will support with the SupportedEncodingProperties property.
segment.target: Set the encoding properties your effect will support with the SupportedEncodingProperties property.

segment.source: When working with Win2D, you must use ARGB32 encoding.
segment.target: When working with Win2D, you must use ARGB32 encoding.

segment.source: SupportedEncodingPropertiesWin2D
segment.target: SupportedEncodingPropertiesWin2D

segment.source: Use the SetEncodingProperties method to create a new Win2D CanvasDevice object from the IDirect3DDevice passed into the method.
segment.target: Use the SetEncodingProperties method to create a new Win2D CanvasDevice object from the IDirect3DDevice passed into the method.

segment.source: SetEncodingPropertiesWin2D
segment.target: SetEncodingPropertiesWin2D

segment.source: The SetProperties implementation is identical to the software processing example above.
segment.target: The SetProperties implementation is identical to the software processing example above.

segment.source: This example uses a BlurAmount property to configure a Win2D blur effect.
segment.target: This example uses a BlurAmount property to configure a Win2D blur effect.

segment.source: SetPropertiesWin2D
segment.target: SetPropertiesWin2D

segment.source: BlurAmountWin2D
segment.target: BlurAmountWin2D

segment.source: The last step is to implement the ProcessFrame method that actually processes the image data.
segment.target: The last step is to implement the ProcessFrame method that actually processes the image data.

segment.source: Using Win2D APIs, a CanvasBitmap is created from the input frame's Direct3DSurface property.
segment.target: Using Win2D APIs, a CanvasBitmap is created from the input frame's Direct3DSurface property.

segment.source: A CanvasRenderTarget is created from the output frame's Direct3DSurface and a CanvasDrawingSession is created from this render target.
segment.target: A CanvasRenderTarget is created from the output frame's Direct3DSurface and a CanvasDrawingSession is created from this render target.

segment.source: A new Win2D GaussianBlurEffect is initialized, using the BlurAmount property our effect exposes via SetProperties.
segment.target: A new Win2D GaussianBlurEffect is initialized, using the BlurAmount property our effect exposes via SetProperties.

segment.source: Finally, the CanvasDrawingSession.DrawImage method is called to draw the input bitmap to the render target using the blur effect.
segment.target: Finally, the CanvasDrawingSession.DrawImage method is called to draw the input bitmap to the render target using the blur effect.

segment.source: ProcessFrameWin2D
segment.target: ProcessFrameWin2D

segment.source: Adding your custom effect to your app
segment.target: Adding your custom effect to your app

segment.source: In order to use your video effect from your app, you must add a reference to the effect project to your app.
segment.target: In order to use your video effect from your app, you must add a reference to the effect project to your app.

segment.source: In Solution Explorer, under your app project, right-click References and select Add reference...
segment.target: In Solution Explorer, under your app project, right-click References and select Add reference...

segment.source: Expand the Projects tab, click Solution, and select the checkbox for your effect project name.
segment.target: Expand the Projects tab, click Solution, and select the checkbox for your effect project name.

segment.source: For this example, the name is VideoEffectComponent.
segment.target: For this example, the name is VideoEffectComponent.

segment.source: Click OK.
segment.target: Click OK.

segment.source: Add your custom effect to a camera video stream
segment.target: Add your custom effect to a camera video stream

segment.source: You can set up a simple preview stream from the camera by following the steps in the article Simple camera preview access.
segment.target: You can set up a simple preview stream from the camera by following the steps in the article Simple camera preview access.

segment.source: Following those steps will provide you with an initialized MediaCapture object that is used to access the camera's video stream.
segment.target: Following those steps will provide you with an initialized MediaCapture object that is used to access the camera's video stream.

segment.source: To add your custom video effect to a camera stream, first create a new VideoEffectDefinition object, passing in the namespace and class name for your effect.
segment.target: To add your custom video effect to a camera stream, first create a new VideoEffectDefinition object, passing in the namespace and class name for your effect.

segment.source: Next call the MediaCapture object's AddVideoEffect method to add your effect to the specified stream.
segment.target: Next call the MediaCapture object's AddVideoEffect method to add your effect to the specified stream.

segment.source: This example uses the MediaStreamType.VideoPreview value to specify that the effect should be added to the preview stream.
segment.target: This example uses the MediaStreamType.VideoPreview value to specify that the effect should be added to the preview stream.

segment.source: If your app supports video capture, you could also use MediaStreamType.VideoRecord to add the effect to the capture stream.
segment.target: If your app supports video capture, you could also use MediaStreamType.VideoRecord to add the effect to the capture stream.

segment.source: AddVideoEffect returns an IMediaExtension object representing your custom effect.
segment.target: AddVideoEffect returns an IMediaExtension object representing your custom effect.

segment.source: You can use the SetProperties method to set the configuration for your effect.
segment.target: You can use the SetProperties method to set the configuration for your effect.

segment.source: Once the effect has been added, StartPreviewAsync is called to start the preview stream.
segment.target: Once the effect has been added, StartPreviewAsync is called to start the preview stream.

segment.source: AddVideoEffectAsync
segment.target: AddVideoEffectAsync

segment.source: Add your custom effect to a clip in a MediaComposition
segment.target: Add your custom effect to a clip in a MediaComposition

segment.source: For general guidance oncreating media compositions from video clips, see Media compositions and editing.
segment.target: For general guidance oncreating media compositions from video clips, see Media compositions and editing.

segment.source: The following code snippet shows the creation of a simple media composition with using a custom video effect.
segment.target: The following code snippet shows the creation of a simple media composition with using a custom video effect.

segment.source: A MediaClip object is created by calling CreateFromFileAsync, passing in a video file that was selected by the user with a FileOpenPicker and the clip is added to a new MediaComposition.
segment.target: A MediaClip object is created by calling CreateFromFileAsync, passing in a video file that was selected by the user with a FileOpenPicker and the clip is added to a new MediaComposition.

segment.source: Next a new VideoEffectDefinition object is created, passing in the namespace and class name for your effect to the constructor.
segment.target: Next a new VideoEffectDefinition object is created, passing in the namespace and class name for your effect to the constructor.

segment.source: Finally, the effect definition is added to the VideoEffectDefinitions collection of the MediaClip object.
segment.target: Finally, the effect definition is added to the VideoEffectDefinitions collection of the MediaClip object.

segment.source: AddEffectToComposition
segment.target: AddEffectToComposition

segment.target: Related topics
